stream_context.summary: Kaze focused on designing and prototyping the environment for Course 14, a level with a cardboard and crafts theme. The main activities involved brainstorming and implementing the background, death floor, and overall aesthetic, including creating a 'shiny paint' effect and solving visual problems like Z-fighting and hiding the horizon.

development_findings.summary: The craft-themed level (Course 14) is designed as a self-contained diorama to prevent players from thinking they can explore a larger environment, thus making the death floor feel more natural.
development_findings.quote: The one reason I want to maybe not make this course be on a giant table is that if I do that, it looks like you can go to the bottom. And I want there to be a death floor.

development_findings.summary: A 'shiny paint' effect was implemented for the background using a computationally cheap fake normal map, causing highlights to shift with the camera's position.
development_findings.quote: Shall I add a fake normal map to this? So that when you turn the camera, there's like highlights like this moving. Oh, that would look so good.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is conscious that the open design of Course 14 presents a significant performance challenge on N64 hardware, requiring careful management of polygon count and overdraw.
development_findings.quote: This level is gonna be very difficult to make run well on N64 because of how open it is.

development_findings.summary: The team is experimenting with various craft materials for level elements, including glue patches that slow Mario, tape to create seams, and rejecting certain ideas like a visible glue bottle to maintain a 'finished' diorama look.
The death floor for the craft level will be represented by a texture resembling gift wrap or blue aluminum foil to simulate water, with cardboard mountains hiding the horizon line.
Kaze debugged a crash caused by a collision node overflow, which occurred when too many collision objects were present in the level.
To complete the diorama aesthetic, the entire level will be framed by an infinitely distant background of a room, resembling a Toad House from Super Mario 64.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has hired a video editor and is strategically planning YouTube content, which he now considers 'the job', distinct from the 'fun part' of actual game development.
context_findings.quote: For me, YouTube at this point... This is the job part and like making the game is the fun part.

context_findings.summary: Kaze deliberately avoids using or discussing content from the Nintendo Gigaleak due to fear of legal repercussions from Nintendo, who he feels already targets his YouTube channel.
context_findings.quote: I on purpose stayed away from the giga league as much as I could because I figured if I ever look at the giga league and do content with it, they're gonna completely murder me.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is considering making a video about his previous hack, 'The Missing Link', which was taken down by Nintendo, and plans to re-release it at some point.
context_findings.quote: The mod Nintendo doesn't want you to know about. The missing link. I could talk about the hack I made that Nintendo took down. Maybe make a small version update. I think this one would go hard.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes that 'Paper Mario: The Origami King' was a failed experiment by Nintendo to create a game driven purely by intrinsic motivation, lacking a satisfying reward system.
context_findings.quote: Nintendo did to see how fun they can make a game with zero extrinsic motivation. The entire game just exists for you to play it for the sake of playing it. And it failed.

context_findings.summary: Kaze wants to create a video arguing that the N64's main bottleneck is the RSP, not memory, but is delaying it until he has a more complete understanding to ensure accuracy.
context_findings.quote: I'm not entirely comfortable making this video yet, because there's so much RSP stuff I don't understand yet.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses frustration with the common defense of Nintendo's past development choices, feeling that the 'it was 1996' argument stifles critical analysis of the final product.
context_findings.quote: Whenever I say something that's slightly critical of a decision they made I get so many comments being like but Kaze it was 1996.

biobak.summary: Biobak is currently working on the remake of Course 1, which is a required component for the game's demo.
Biobak provided the core concept for the cardboard level's background: a large paper cylinder with drawings on it, which Kaze adopted.
biobak.quote: Biobak was suggesting that there would be like... That this whole thing would be inside a paper cylinder. And the paper cylinder is gonna have stuff drawn onto it.

zeina.summary: Zeina (Eiza) collaborated with Kaze on a 'slide deck' to plan Course 15, allowing Kaze to pre-program the necessary assets and significantly speed up the level's development.
zeina.quote: Course 15 is also already halfway done because I already programmed all the assets for it, for the slide deck I made with Eiza.

key_stories.title: Designing the Diorama Background
key_stories.summary: Kaze needed to create a convincing world for the craft-themed level. He struggled with how to implement a death floor without it feeling arbitrary, ultimately deciding on a diorama concept suggested by Biobak. The stream showed his iterative process of building this concept, from texturing the walls to creating a 'shiny paint' effect and designing a 'wrapping paper' water floor.
key_stories.challenge: How to design a background and death floor for a craft-themed level that is aesthetically cohesive and clearly communicates gameplay boundaries.
key_stories.process: Kaze rejected an open 'desk' concept to avoid player confusion. He adopted Biobak's idea of a paper cylinder, then prototyped a seam with tape, iterated through numerous textures for the floor and sky, and developed a custom 'shiny paint' shader to enhance the visual effect.
key_stories.outcome: A clear design direction was established: the level is a diorama inside a cylindrical paper wall with a painted sky and a 'wrapping paper' water floor. The edges will be hidden by cardboard mountains, and the entire scene is framed by a distant room background.
key_stories.key_quote: The one reason I want to maybe not make this course be on a giant table is that if I do that, it looks like you can go to the bottom. And I want there to be a death floor.

key_stories.title: The 'Missing Link' Takedown and Rerelease Plan
key_stories.summary: While planning future YouTube content, Kaze revealed his intention to create a video about his hack 'The Missing Link,' which Nintendo had previously forced him to take down. He also expressed a strong desire to update and re-release the hack, turning a past conflict with Nintendo into a future project.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze's popular hack 'The Missing Link' was previously taken down by Nintendo, leaving its story untold and the project unavailable.
key_stories.process: While brainstorming a list of over 20 potential YouTube video ideas with his stream chat, Kaze identified the story of his delisted hack as a high-potential topic and explicitly stated his desire to bring the project back.
key_stories.outcome: The project remains dormant, but Kaze has a clear plan to revive it, both by creating a YouTube video detailing the takedown story and by eventually re-releasing an updated version of the hack.
key_stories.key_quote: I could talk about the hack I made that Nintendo took down. Maybe make a small version update. I think this one would go hard. And I definitely want to re-release missing link at some point.
